reaction.text: Hydrolysis of terminal non-reducing beta-D-galactose residues in beta-D-galactosides.

comment.text: Binds 2 magnesium ions per monomer. Can also use manganese.
Inhibited by phenylethyl thio-beta-D-galactoside (PETG), isopropyl thio-beta-D-galactoside (IPTG), L-ribose, D-galactonolactone, lactose and 2-amino-D-galactose.

kinetics.KM: 34 uM for p-nitrophenyl beta-D-galactoside (with magnesium as cofactor and 30 degrees Celsius)
140 uM for o-nitrophenyl beta-D-galactoside (with magnesium as cofactor and 30 degrees Celsius)
940 uM for allolactose (with magnesium as cofactor and 30 degrees Celsius)
1350 uM for lactose (with magnesium as cofactor and 30 degrees Celsius)
kinetics.Vmax: 30.9 umol/min/mg enzyme with lactose as substrate (with magnesium as cofactor and 30 degrees Celsius)
49.7 umol/min/mg enzyme with allolactose as substrate (with magnesium as cofactor and 30 degrees Celsius)
59.7 umol/min/mg enzyme with p-nitrophenyl beta-D-galactoside as substrate (with magnesium as cofactor and 30 degrees Celsius)
360 umol/min/mg enzyme with o-nitrophenyl beta-D-galactoside as substrate (with magnesium as cofactor and 30 degrees Celsius)
kinetics.text: The values for the enzymatic assays using manganese as cofactor are very close.

comment.text: Belongs to the glycosyl hydrolase 2 family.

feature.description: Important for ensuring that an appropriate proportion of lactose is converted to allolactose
Causes a significant decrease in binding affinity in the absence of monovalent cations or in the presence of potassium ions, but only a moderate decrease in the presence of sodium ions.
Less stable to heat than wild-type. Causes significant destabilizations of the first transition state.
Essentially inactive unless very rapid purification. Causes very large destabilizations of the transition state.
Slowly inactivates galactosidase activity by reducing the binding of magnesium. It increases binding specificity.
Poorly reactive with galactosyl substrates. Less stable to heat than wild-type.
Decreases the stability of the loop 794-804.
It forces the apoenzyme to adopt the closed rather than the open conformation. Reduces the binding affinity.
The catalytic efficiency is not increased, when the sodium concentration increases.
Small increase of the catalytic efficiency, when the sodium concentration increases.
